name: Technical Interview
description: Key phrases for handling incident management interviews, focusing on client containment, prioritization, and cross-regional communication.

cards.sideA: Debo contener al cliente en Japón y Corea.

sideB.text: I must manage the client in Japan and Korea.
I need to keep the client in Japan and Korea contained.
My role involves managing expectations for clients in Japan and Korea.

cards.note:
To [contain] a client in an IT context often means to manage their anxiety or keep a situation under control. [Manage expectations] is also a very professional alternative.

~I must to contain~ is incorrect. Modal verbs like [must] are followed directly by the verb.

~...client from Japan...~ (Preposition: 'En Japón' translates to 'in Japan' (location). 'From Japan' implies origin.)

cards.sideA: Debo ser el puente entre Japón, Corea y usted en EE. UU.

sideB.text: I must be the bridge between Japan, Korea, and you in the USA.
I need to act as the liaison between Japan, Korea, and your team in the US.
My job is to serve as the link between Japan, Korea, and the US side.

cards.note:
[Liaison] is a high-level professional term for 'puente' or 'enlace' in business communication.

Preposition: [Between] is used when connecting distinct entities (Japan, Korea, and USA).

cards.sideA: Lo primero es definir la prioridad: baja, media o alta.

sideB.text: The first step is to define the priority: low, medium, or high.
First, I need to determine the priority level: low, medium, or high.
The first thing to do is assess the severity and set the priority: low, medium, or high.

cards.note:
[First step] or [First thing] are natural ways to start a process description.

[Assess the severity] is a strong technical phrase often used before assigning a priority.

cards.sideA: Le pediría al cliente que abra un ticket.

sideB.text: I would ask the client to open a ticket.
I'd request the client to submit a support ticket.
I would tell the client to log a ticket for the issue.

cards.note:
Standard verbs for tickets: [Open], [Submit], [Log], or [Raise].

Structure: [Ask someone TO DO something]. ~Ask that the client opens~ is possible but less common in spoken English.

cards.sideA: Si veo que el problema es grave, le pediría más información.

sideB.text: If I see that the problem is serious, I would ask for more information.
If I notice it's a critical issue, I'd request further details.
If the issue appears severe, I would ask for more context.
If I see that the problem is serious, I would ask for further information.

cards.note:
Conditionals: [If I see... I would ask] (Mixed conditional often used in interviews to describe hypothetical reactions to real situations).

Vocabulary: [Critical] or [Severe] are excellent synonyms for 'grave' in IT.

~...ask further information~ (Grammar: The verb 'ask' requires the preposition 'for' when requesting something: 'ask for information'.)

cards.sideA: Le pediría más información para tener un resumen más completo del problema.

sideB.text: I would ask for more information to have a more complete summary of the problem.
I'd request more details to get a full picture of the issue.
I would ask for further info to ensure I have a comprehensive overview of the situation.

cards.note:
[To get a full picture] is a great idiom for understanding the whole situation.

[Comprehensive overview] sounds very professional in an interview setting.

~...summary much more complete...~ (Word order: Adjectives usually come before the noun, e.g., 'a much more complete summary'.)

cards.sideA: Luego le diría al cliente que me contactaré con el DBA o el encargado de redes.

sideB.text: Then I would tell the client that I will contact the DBA or the Network manager.
After that, I'd inform the client that I'm reaching out to the DBA or the Network lead.
Then I'd let the client know I'll get in touch with the DBA or the Networking team.

cards.note:
Phrasal Verb: [Reach out to] or [Get in touch with] are very natural alternatives to [Contact].

Structure: [Tell the client THAT...]. Avoid ~Tell to the client~.

cards.sideA: Tengo que definir el área, por ejemplo, si es de redes o DBA.

sideB.text: I have to define the area, for example, if it is Networks or DBA.
I need to identify the domain, for instance, whether it's a Network or Database issue.
I must determine the responsible team, like Networking or the DBA group.

cards.note:
[Identify the domain] or [Determine the responsible team] shows analytical skills.

DBA stands for [Database Administrator].

cards.sideA: También puedo verificar si el problema es específico de ellos o es general.

sideB.text: I can also verify if the problem is specific to them or if it is general.
I can also check if it's an isolated issue or a widespread one.
I would also investigate whether the issue is local to them or affecting everyone.
I can also verify if the problem is specific to them or it is for everyone.

cards.note:
IT Vocabulary: [Isolated] (specific to one user/area) vs. [Widespread] (affecting many).

Use [Check] or [Investigate] as synonyms for verify.

~...specific for them...~ (Collocation: When describing exclusivity or limitation, use 'specific to'.)

cards.sideA: También puedo verificar si el problema es para Japón o general para todos.

sideB.text: I can also verify if the problem is for Japan or general for everyone.
I can also check if the issue is region-specific to Japan or global.
I need to confirm if it's just affecting Japan or if it's a global outage.

cards.note:
[Region-specific] is a precise technical term.

[Global outage] implies the system is down for everyone.

~...problem is from Japan...~ (Preposition error: Use 'in Japan' for location. 'From' implies origin.)

cards.sideA: Luego de recibir la respuesta del DBA, puedo comunicarme con el cliente.

sideB.text: After receiving the response from the DBA, I can communicate with the client.
Once I hear back from the DBA, I can get back to the client.
Upon getting a reply from the DBA, I'll update the client.
After receiving the answer from the DBA, I can communicate with the client.

cards.note:
Phrasal Verbs: [Hear back from] (receive a reply) and [Get back to] (respond to someone) are essential for fluent communication.

[Update the client] is more active and professional than just 'communicate'.

cards.sideA: Luego de recibir la respuesta del encargado de redes, puedo darle una respuesta al cliente.

sideB.text: After receiving the response from the Network manager, I can give an answer to the client.
Once the Network lead responds, I can provide the client with an update.
After getting the info from the Network team, I can relay the answer to the client.
After receiving the response from the Network Team, I can provide an answer to the client.

cards.note:
[Relay the answer] means to pass information from one person to another.

[Provide an update] is standard customer service language.

cards.sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será Microsoft Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be Microsoft Teams.
Our primary communication channel will be Microsoft Teams.
We will primarily use Microsoft Teams to communicate.
Our main tool of communication will be Microsoft Teams.

cards.note:
[Primary communication channel] sounds very professional.

Use [Will be] for established future plans.

cards.sideA: Nuestro principal medio de comunicación será por chat o llamadas por Teams.

sideB.text: Our main means of communication will be via chat or Teams calls.
We'll communicate mainly through Teams chat or calls.
Our primary contact methods will be Teams chat and calls.

cards.note:
[Via] is a useful preposition meaning 'by way of' (e.g., via chat, via email).

[Through] is also commonly used (e.g., through Teams).

~Our main tool... will be by chat...~ (Mismatch: A 'tool' is a noun [Teams]. If you use 'by chat' [method], start with 'Our main method of communication...' or 'We will communicate by...')

cards.sideA: Para ser honesto, no se mas sobre la compañía.

sideB.text: To be honest, I don't know much more about the company.
Honestly, I don't know anything else about the company.
To tell you the truth, I don't have any more info on the company.

cards.note:
[To be honest] and [Honestly] are the standard idioms for 'Para ser honesto/La verdad'.

Note the difference: 'No sé más' usually means [I don't know anything else] or [I don't know much more], not ~I don't know plus~.

~To be honest, I don't know more about the company.~ (Incomplete phrasing: Use 'anything else' or 'much more' to express lack of further information.)

cards.sideA: Asi que puedo tomar otro trabajo en la noche facilmente.

sideB.text: So I can easily pick up another job at night.
So I can take on another evening job easily.
That means I can easily get another job at night.
So, I can take another job at night easily.

cards.note:
The phrasal verbs [pick up] or [take on] a job are very natural for casual or secondary employment.

Adverbs like [easily] often go before the main verb: [I can easily pick up...].

cards.sideA: Es esencial que documenten los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is essential that they document the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's crucial to document the reproduction steps for the bug.
They essentially need to document how to reproduce the defect.

cards.note:
[Steps to Reproduce] is the standard technical term in QA tickets. ~Steps of reproduction~ is less common.

The structure [It is essential that they document...] is formal and correct.

cards.sideA: Es necesario que compartan los pasos de Reproducción del defecto.

sideB.text: It is necessary that they share the Steps to Reproduce the defect.
It's necessary for them to share the reproduction steps.
They need to share the steps to reproduce the bug.

cards.note:
You can use the structure [It is necessary for them to share...] or the simpler [They need to share...].

Avoid ~It is necessary that they shares~ (incorrect verb conjugation).

cards.sideA: Necesito preguntar: "¿Como reproducir el problema?"

sideB.text: I need to ask: 'How to reproduce the issue?'
I need to ask how to reproduce the problem.
I have to ask: 'How do you reproduce the bug?'

cards.note:
If asking directly, use the full question structure: [How do you reproduce...?].

If using the short form (headline style) in a ticket or list, [How to reproduce the issue] is acceptable.

cards.sideA: Es necesario depurar para encontrar la causa raiz del problema.

sideB.text: Debugging is necessary to find the root cause of the problem.
We need to debug to find the root cause.
It's necessary to debug to locate the root cause.

cards.note:
[Root cause] is the specific technical term for 'causa raíz'.

[Debugging] (gerund) acts as the subject. Alternatively, use [We need to debug].

cards.sideA: No sentía que estaba progresando en ese rol.

sideB.text: I didn't feel I was really progressing in that role.
I felt stuck, like the role wasn't letting me grow.
I didn't feel like I was moving forward in that position.
I felt like I wasn't really progressing in that role.

cards.note:
[Progressing] and [moving forward] are good translations for 'progresando'.

[I felt stuck] (me sentía estancado) is a very common idiom to express the lack of progress.

cards.sideA: Los errores cosméticos—como problemas de espaciado o colores, son de baja prioridad.

sideB.text: Cosmetic bugs—like spacing or color issues—are low priority.
Cosmetic errors, such as spacing or colors, are low priority.
Visual bugs like spacing or color problems are considered low priority.

cards.note:
[Cosmetic bugs] or [Cosmetic issues] refer to things that look wrong but work correctly.

[Low priority] is the standard classification. ~Low importance~ is less technical.

~...space or color bugs...~ (Vocabulary: In UI/Design, use 'spacing' to refer to the distance between elements. 'Space' usually refers to the outer void or available room.)

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de producción—como problemas en el carro, son de alta prioridad.

sideB.text: A production blocker—like cart issues—is high priority.
A production blocker, such as an issue with the cart, is a high priority.
Production blockers like cart problems are top priority.

cards.note:
[Blocker] is a noun in IT meaning a bug that stops testing or usage.

[High priority] or [Top priority] are standard terms.

cards.sideA: Un bloqueo de alta prioridad en producción—se debe escalar inmediatamente.

sideB.text: A high priority production blocker must be escalated immediately.
We need to escalate high-priority production blockers immediately.
Any high-priority blocker in production has to be escalated right away.

cards.note:
[To escalate] means to pass the issue to a higher level of authority or technical support.

[Immediately] or [right away] emphasizes urgency.

cards.sideA: Un error cosmético de UI—se puede agendar y solucionar con más calma.

sideB.text: A cosmetic UI error can be scheduled and fixed with less urgency.
We can schedule cosmetic UI bugs to be fixed later.
Cosmetic UI issues can be prioritized for later.

cards.note:
[To schedule] in this context means to put it in the backlog for a future sprint.

[With less urgency] or [later] translates 'con más calma' in a professional context.

~A cosmetic issue of UI~ (Word Order: Use 'UI issue' or 'UI error'. In English, nouns often act as adjectives before the main noun.)

cards.sideA: Debo priorizar si es un error cosmético o un bloqueo de producción.

sideB.text: I have to prioritize if it's a cosmetic bug or a production blocker.
I need to determine if it's a cosmetic issue or a blocker.
I must prioritize based on whether it's cosmetic or a production blocker.

cards.note:
[Prioritize] means to decide the order of importance.

Using [whether... or...] is slightly more formal and precise than [if... or...], but both are used.

cards.sideA: Si un cliente me dice sobre un error...

sideB.text: If a client tells me about an issue...
If a client reports a bug...
If a client lets me know about an error...

cards.note:
[Reports a bug] is standard industry terminology.

~If a client says me~ is incorrect. You [tell someone] or [say to someone].

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal todavía puede hacer lo que necesita, es cosmético.

sideB.text: If a normal user can still get what they need done, it's cosmetic.
If a standard user can still perform their tasks, it's a cosmetic issue.
It's cosmetic if a regular user can still do what they need to do.
If a normal user can still do what they need, it's cosmetic.

cards.note:
[Get what they need done] is a very natural way to express 'hacer lo que necesitan'.

[Standard user] or [Regular user] are good translations for 'usuario normal'.

cards.sideA: Si un usuario normal no puede hacer lo que necesita, es un bloqueo.

sideB.text: If a normal user can't get what they need done, it's a blocker.
If a regular user is unable to complete their task, it's a blocker.
It's a blocker if a standard user can't do what they need.
If a normal user can't do what they need, it's a blocker.

cards.note:
In this context, [a blocker] acts as a noun (un bloqueo).

~Is a locking~ is unnatural; use [Blocker].

cards.sideA: Como estaba diciendo, como es solo un error cosmético, necesitamos...

sideB.text: As I was saying, since it's just a cosmetic bug, we need to...
As I mentioned, because this is only a cosmetic error, we need to...
Like I said, as it's just cosmetic, we need to...

cards.note:
[As I was saying] is excellent for resuming a point after an interruption.

Avoid using 'how' for cause. ~How is a cosmetic bug...~ is incorrect. Use [Since], [As], or [Because].

~...how it is just...~ (False Friend: 'How' is not used for causation here. Use 'since', 'as', or 'because' to translate 'como' in this context.)

cards.sideA: Como es un bloqueo en producción, necesitamos...

sideB.text: Since it's a production blocker, we need to...
Because it's a production blocker, we need to...
As this is a blocker in production, we must...

cards.note:
Use [Since] or [Because] to explain the reason.

[In production] refers to the live environment.

cards.sideA: Ese es un fallo funcional—no bloquea a nadie, pero los números no cuadran.

sideB.text: That's a functional glitch—it's not blocking anyone, but the numbers are off.
That's a functional bug; it doesn't block users, but the numbers don't add up.
It's a functional issue—nobody is blocked, but the figures are incorrect.

cards.note:
[Glitch] is often used for minor, transient, or strange errors.

[The numbers are off] is a very common idiom meaning calculations are incorrect.

[Don't add up] also means the math is wrong or the situation doesn't make sense.

~...the numbers don't fit.~ (Vocabulary: Use 'don't match', 'don't add up', or 'are off'. 'Fit' usually refers to physical size or shape.)

cards.sideA: Como es un fallo funcional, es de media prioridad.

sideB.text: Since it's a functional glitch, it's medium priority.
Because it's a functional error, it's medium priority.
As it is a functional bug, we'll treat it as medium priority.

cards.note:
[Medium priority] is the standard classification between Low and High.

Use [Since] or [Because] to link the cause (functional glitch) to the effect (priority).

cards.sideA: El flujo de usuario que desencadena el problema.

sideB.text: The user flow that triggers the issue.
The user journey that causes the problem.
The sequence of actions that sets off the bug.

cards.note:
[User flow] or [User journey] are standard terms for the path a user takes in the application.

[Triggers] is the specific technical verb for causing a piece of code or event to run. ~The flow that starts the problem~ is less precise.

cards.sideA: Necesito saber el exacto flujo del usuario para desencadenar el problema.

sideB.text: I need to know the exact user flow to trigger the issue.
I need to understand the precise steps the user took to cause the problem.
I require the exact user path that sets off the error.

cards.note:
Use [Exact] or [Precise] to emphasize the need for detail in debugging.

Structure: [To trigger the issue] indicates the purpose/result of the flow.

cards.sideA: Necesito saber cómo reproducir o desencadenar el problema.

sideB.text: I need to know how to reproduce or trigger the issue.
I need to figure out how to replicate or set off the problem.
I must know how to recreate or trigger the bug.

cards.note:
[Reproduce] and [Replicate] are the most common verbs in QA to describe copying the error conditions.

[Set off] is a good phrasal verb synonym for [Trigger].

cards.sideA: Entiendo que en este rol debo ser muy proactivo.

sideB.text: I understand that I must be quite proactive in this role.
I realize that I need to be very proactive in this position.
I understand that high proactivity is required in this role.

cards.note:
[Quite] usually means 'very' or 'considerably' in this context.

[Proactive] (taking initiative) is a key soft skill keyword for senior roles.

cards.sideA: Mientras tanto, empiezo a replicar los pasos exactos en mi propia máquina.

sideB.text: So, meanwhile I start replicating the exact steps on my own machine.
In the meantime, I'll begin reproducing the exact steps on my local machine.
Meanwhile, I am starting to replicate the specific steps on my computer.

cards.note:
[Meanwhile] or [In the meantime] connects two simultaneous actions (the user talking/waiting and you testing).

[Local machine] or [My own machine] refers to your development environment.

cards.sideA: Hola, gracias, lo estoy comprobando/revisando ahora mismo.

sideB.text: Hi, thanks—checking right now.
Hello, thanks. I'm looking into it right now.
Hi, thank you. I am checking on that immediately.
Hi, thanks— I'm checking it right now.

cards.note:
[Looking into it] is a professional phrasal verb meaning to investigate.

In chat contexts (Teams/Slack), omitting the subject [I am] (e.g., 'Checking right now') is acceptable and common.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes compartir tu flujo de usuario?

sideB.text: Can you share your user flow?
Could you please share the user flow you followed?
Would you mind sharing your user path?

cards.note:
[Could you] or [Would you mind] makes the request more polite than just 'Can you'.

[User flow] is the standard term for the sequence of steps.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes describir exactamente lo que hiciste?

sideB.text: Can you describe exactly what you did?
Could you explain the exact actions you took?
Can you detail precisely what you did?

cards.note:
[Actions you took] is a formal way to say 'what you did'.

~Can you describe me~ is incorrect. You describe [something] TO [someone], or just describe [something].

cards.sideA: Lo intentaré ahora mismo y veré si obtengo el mismo problema/error.

sideB.text: I'll try it right now and see if I get the same issue.
I'm going to attempt it immediately to see if I encounter the same error.
I will try that now and check if I face the same problem.

cards.note:
[Encounter an error] or [Face a problem] are good alternatives to 'get'.

[I'll try it] (Future with Will) is used for decisions made at the moment of speaking.

cards.sideA: ¿Puedes darme exactamente los pasos que hiciste para llegar ahí?

sideB.text: Can you give me the exact steps you took to get there?
Could you provide the specific steps you followed to reach that point?
Can you tell me the exact steps you took to arrive at that state?

cards.note:
[Steps you took] is the colocation for 'pasos que hiciste'. ~Steps you made~ is unnatural.

[To get there] refers to arriving at the error state.

~...steps that you did...~ (Collocation: We 'take' or 'follow' steps, we do not 'do' them.)

cards.sideA: Estoy siguiendo los pasos justo ahora.

sideB.text: I'm following along right now.
I'm following the steps right now.
I am going through the steps at this very moment.

cards.note:
[Following along] implies you are doing the action in parallel with the description or the other person.

[Going through the steps] is a common phrasal verb for executing a procedure.
